title: I’ve never written a book before. What tips can a beginner use? - Quora

response.answer_text: Since I was 6, I knew I wanted to be a writer. I thought that every writer needs to sit down and write the whole book in one set. I know it’s pure madness. Here’s why. I didn’t have the habit to write. I didn’t know the process. With those 5 books , you will kick off your writing career. 1. The Achievement Habit By Bernard Roth  Image from here Admit it… writing is hard. It’s natural to feel discouraged. “Maybe I am not good enough” you may whisper. That’s why before getting your hands dirty with the actual business, you have to fix your broken spirit and bring your old soul back to life. It all starts with the mindset. I had the privilege to meet the co-founder of the Stanford School of Design, Bernard Roth during the study mission.  The Civic Tech Leadership Program selected participants with Bernard Roth at the D. School We had an interesting conversation about design thinking. He is famous for his book The Achievement Habit. “In The Achievement Habit, Roth applies the remarkable insights that stem from design thinking — previously used to solve large scale projects — to help us realize the power for positive change we all have within us. Roth leads us through a series of discussions, stories, recommendations, and exercises designed to help us create a different experience in our lives.” 2. Rework By Jason Fried And David Heinmeier Hansson  Image from here Most writers think that great content will save them all the time. Think about Mel Robbins for example. She is the most in demand female speaker in the world.  Mel Robbins This lady has built an 8 figure business off her speaking. I won’t deny that she is skilled. The same goes for you. If you wanna live off your writing, you need to learn to do good business. Jason Fried And DHH, co-founders of Basecamp wrote an unusual business best seller called Rework. How unusual? Carry on reading. “Most business books give you the same old advice: Write a business plan, study the competition, seek investors, yadda yadda. If you’re looking for a book like that, put this one back on the shelf. With its straightforward language and easy-is-better approach, Rework is the perfect playbook for anyone who’s ever dreamed of doing it on their own. Hardcore entrepreneurs, small-business owners, people stuck in day jobs they hate, victims of “downsizing,” and artists who don’t want to starve anymore will all find valuable guidance in these pages.” 3. Confessions Of A Teenage Gamer By Nicole Cole  Image from here Having the motivation , the mindset and the knowledge to execute sometimes is not enough. You are still scared: what if I fail so bad? or maybe I am too young for this? Your concerns are valid. What if I told you that someone as young as you did it already. To make it even harder, he comes from an unusual background: video games. Look no further than Nicolas Cole , a top Quora writer, an Inc magazine columnist and an entrepreneur at only 27. Nicole wasn’t always like this. In his teen years, he was one of the most famous WOW players in North America.  World of warcraft Gameplay Screenshot He wrote a book illustrating this experience entitled Confessions Of A Teenage Gamer: “When people think of World of Warcraft, they think of a socially awkward, acne-faced teenager with “no life.” Confessions of a Teenage Gamer challenges those stereotypes and shows how a kid from a wealthy family with every opportunity at his fingertips ended up finding himself in a video game.” 4. Real Artists Don’t Starve By Jeff Goins  Image from here Up to this point, you have general knowledge. You wish the genie of the magic lamp would come out and hand you a detailed road-map. Come on, we both know genies don’t exist, do they? Famous author Jeff Goins is here to save your day. He may not have super powers. But, he has an amazing book to guide you through your journey. Below, a sneak peak of Real Artists Don’t Starve: “Bestselling author Jeff Goins dismantles the myth that being creative is a hindrance to success by revealing how an artistic temperament is in fact a competitive advantage. From graphic designers and writers to artists and business professionals, creatives already know that no one is born an artist. Goins’ revolutionary rules celebrate the process of becoming an artist, a person who utilizes the imagination in fundamental ways.” 5. Content Machine: Use Content Marketing to Build A 7-figure Business With Zero Advertising By Dan Norris  Image from here Most writers don’t sell well not because they suck as writers. They are terrible marketers. Best selling author, Dan Norris succeeded to do that over the past 5 years. Thus his book Content Machine: Use Content Marketing to Build a 7-figure Business With Zero Advertising saw the light: “Content Machine outlines a strategy for using content marketing to build a 7 figure business with zero advertising. Author Dan Norris shares his story about how he grew his WordPress support business from scratch to over $1m AUD annual run rate in 2 years, spending only $181.23 on advertising. The lessons learned form a framework for building businesses and scaling content marketing, that are documented throughout Content Machine in terms any entrepreneur can understand.“ At the end of the day, writing is a support. Your first book will suck. Your second book will also suck. But things will get easier, no worries. And in case you are wondering, I am now a full time content marketer for a tech startup. Currently working on the outline of my first book.

If you have never written a book, but has written short stories, essays or poems you have a good start. Otherwise you’ll need more time. The first thing you must absolute decide is what type of book you want to write. A novel is quite a complex task to be undertaken by a newbie, I think you’d better start with short stories. Even if you do want to write your own autobiography, it’s a good way to begin structuring it, one step each time. If there’s a long and overarching story to be told (like your autobiography, but it can be a fiction too), your first step is to plan it. Write down your bits of information in small cards and begin ordering them sequentially as they connect to each other. If you want, you can use larger cards and write notes on their backs, but my tip is to give each card a title and a reference number. Then you write bits of text that will be referred to by the titles and numbers on the cards. Don’t use a computer at this stage to prevent losing touch with your history as you fiddle with it and gets distracted by internet and all else. Let the playfulness of shuffling and reshuffling the cards help you develop your ideas and the relationship between them. Collect these cards in a shoe-box (or a proper file if own one or can afford to buy it). Keep adding cards (and bits of information) as you imagine them. Don’t mind with the form at this stage, your goal is to think up every element you’ll need in your book. Among the things you need to write down are the characters (their full names, even if you won’t use this information in the end), their family trees, their relationships, love interests, past affairs, preferences (remember James Bond: ‘stirred, not shaken’), job, physical traits… But you’ll also make such “character cards” for places, buildings, companies, pets, even particular trees or anything that might be relevant to the story. When you have a good-sized collection of cards, it’s time to begin selecting which bits of information you’ll need. The first step here is to categorise your information. Characters go into this shoe-box. Places go into that other. There’s a third for characters that will only be mentioned. A fourth for places nobody will visit, but only talk about. A larger box, drawer or file will contain the scenes you have already written. When you have all properly sorted, pick the most relevant events and the characters and places related to them. Try to imagine ways to bridge these together, if they appear to be broken apart. Ideas you won’t use go into a “slush pile” or a “garbage box”. Don’t throw them away, a writer’s garbage today is the same writer’s treasure tomorrow. When you are sure you have your facts straight, write down a detailed synopsis for them. Keep working in chronological order. Walk before dancing. Now site before your computer, open your favourite text editor (mine’s NeoVim nowadays) and begin writing down each scene in the story. Follow Neruda’s advice: you begin with a capital letter and finish with a period, in-between go your ideas. Write the story sequentially to help you find inconsistencies. If you want your book to tell the story in patchwork way or beginning in media res or any other fancy technique you’ve read about, rework it like that after you have told the story in full and going from A-Z instead of Y-P-A-Z-S-X-C-D-J-M-K and whatever. As you write, try to whisper the words, imagine how they sound. If that’s not sounding good, that’s not good. Don’t overload information, use only what you need and when you need. If the character’s hair colour is not meaningful to the story, don’t even mention he has hair. Don’t shove your vision into the face of your reader, let the reader room to imagine the story his way. Re-read your text after you have finished it. Find someone of your trust to read if for you and find inconsistencies. Re-write the book in your preferred order now. Re-read it again. Ask someone’s opinion about how it reads now it is shuffled (if you have shuffled it). Never hesitate to cut what seems to be excessive and always think twice before you need any information which is not obviously missing and avoid inconsistencies like the plague. If your character must carry his luggage upstairs, don’t mention later that he has checked in to a single-story roadside motel. If your hot lass has undressed fully, don’t let her appear on a window wearing see-through lingerie. Don’t kill the same ancestor in two different ways, unless you make it clear somewhere that your character is a liar, has bad memory or is being lied to. Use appropriate vocabulary. Don’t mention a swarm of fish or a school of birds. If you’re not sure, keep it simple. Don’t lift words from a dictionary to give “polish” to your text: words which don’t live in your heart won’t be warm to your reader, but harsh. And when you’ve written your book, please let me read it.
